Because it is the job of the legislative branch to make laws not the SCOTUS.  Roe was decided on a weak legal argument and left it vulnerable to be overturned. The court is basically saying Roe was incorrect in its legal reasoning, but it is not barring the legislature from enacting laws either allowing or prohibiting abortion. Regardless of what side you are on on this topic, it is far from over from any angle.

The fetus has a heartbeat. In Georgia, it is against the law to perform an abortion if the fetus has a heartbeat. Of those four birth control types, three of them (both pills and the hormone IUD) don't cause abortions.  It takes time for sperm to meet egg, and hormonal emergency contraception (eg Plan B) only works in that time by preventing fertilization entirely. Copper IUDs can in theory prevent implantation if it's inserted within a few days of unprotected sex, but getting one inserted requires an appointment.  It's not intended for use or used in practice as emergency contraception.  Blacklisting it for abortion concerns would be like refusing to cover chemotherapy because it can cause pregnancy loss.

All depends on the size of the estate, case, state law, yada yada.

Correct.  This would be what is known as 'standing' as laid out by article 3 of the constitution.  The long and short of it is that to have standing the plaintiff would need to prove that they were materially damaged by the action of the defendant.  And, violation of a statute alone is not sufficient to establish material damage to the plaintiff. This is more about establishing legal threats and therefore legal costs to clinics I would imagine.  Even if the threats can't really carry any legal weight they require responses in court to dismiss.
